container.heading: PUEBLO OF PICURIS CHILDREN'S CODE

section.heading: Title.
section.text: This title shall be known and may be cited as the "Pueblo of Picuris Children's Code" and references in this title to "Code" shall refer to this Code unless another is clearly indicated.

para.text: It is the purpose of this Children's Code to:
Recognize that the children of the Pueblo of Picuris are its most important resource and their welfare is of paramount importance;

Safeguard, protect, and secure for each child coming under the scope of this Code, the care and guidance, preferably in the child's own home or community, as will serve the emotional, mental and physical welfare of the child and the best interest of the Tribe;
Preserve and strengthen family ties whenever possible; to preserve and strengthen the child's cultural and ethnic identity;
Secure for any child(ren) removed from his/her home the care, guidance and control to help him/her develop into responsible, well-adjusted adults; and
Protect the peace and security of the community and its individual residents.
The Pueblo of Picuris Children's Code shall be liberally interpreted and construed to fulfill the purpose of this Code.
If any Section of the Pueblo of Picuris Children's Code is found to be invalid, the remainder of this Code shall not be affected thereby.

section.heading: Definitions.
section.text: "Abandon" means when a parent or extended family leaves a child without adequate communication or fails to support a child and there is no indication of the parent(s) or extended family's willingness to assume the parental role(s) consistently for a period of no less than six (6) months.
"Abuse" includes physical, emotional, psychological and sexual abuse and are defined as follows.

para.text: "Physical abuse" includes placing a minor knowingly, intentionally, or negligently in a situation that may endanger his/her life or health; knowingly or intentionally torturing, beating, cruelly confining or punishing a minor;

"Emotional abuse" includes systematic patterns of belittling, scapegoating, or other non-physical forms of openly hostile or rejecting actions, as well as excessive non- physical discipline and verbal threats or other forms of maltreatment such as abandonment, beating and sexual assault;
"Sexual abuse" means criminal sexual penetration, incest, criminal sexual contact and non-contact sexual exploitation which are defined as follows:

"Criminal sexual contact of a minor" is when a person unlawfully and intentionally touches or applies force to the intimate parts of a minor who is under eighteen (18) years of age, or causes that minor to touch his/her intimate parts;

"Criminal sexual penetration of a minor" is when a person unlawfully and intentionally causes a minor who is under eighteen (18) years of age, to engage in sexual intercourse, cunnilingus, fellatio or anal intercourse or causes penetration, to any extent and with any object, of the genital or anal openings of another whether or not there is any emission, through the use of coercion that results in personal injury to the victim;

"Incest" is when a person knowingly marries or has sexual intercourse with a person within the following degrees of blood relationship: parents and children, including grandparents and grandchildren of every degree; brothers and sisters of the half, as well as of the whole blood; uncles and nieces/nephews; aunts and nephews/nieces; first degree cousins;

"Non-contact sexual exploitation" is committed when an adult, for their sexual gratification: exposes intimate parts of their body, including the genitals, anus or breasts, to a minor; forces a minor to watch sexual acts or sexual violence; forces the minor to perform sexual acts while being watched by the adult; forces the minor to listen to threats and/or sexual details; or, watches a minor undress.

section.text: "Adult" is a person eighteen (18) years of age or older who is subject to the jurisdiction of the Pueblo of Picuris.
"Child" is a person under fourteen (14) years of age.
"Custodian" is a person other than a parent or guardian who is providing food, shelter, and supervision to a child.
"Contempt of Court" is the willful disobedience or interference of the Court.
"Delinquent Act" is an act committed by a juvenile which is designated a crime under the Pueblo of Picuris Criminal Code.
"Detention Facility" is a facility in which a minor may be placed for a period of temporary custody prior to disposition by the Pueblo of Picuris Juvenile Court.
"Domicile" means the permanent legal residence of an individual. The domicile of a child is presumed to be that of the child's mother unless proven otherwise.

"Extended Family" is a person (tribal member) who has reached the age of eighteen (18), who is the minor's grandparent, aunt or uncle, brother or sister, brother-in-law or sister-in- law, niece or nephew, first or second cousin, stepparent, godparent or traditionally adopted individual.

"Foster Care" is a child welfare service, which provides substitute family care for a child for a period when his/her own family cannot care for them. The goal of foster care or any placement is a permanent family for the child. It includes all out of home care when it is officially sanctioned by Bureau of Indian Affairs Northern Pueblos Agency social services or human services. Out of home care covers, voluntary and involuntary placements. They may be short or long-term, temporary or emergency placement, with a family, group home, or institution.
"Guardian" is a person other than the minor's parent who is by law responsible for the care and custody of that minor or his/her estate or both.
"Guardian Ad Litem" is an adult appointed by the Court who is to represent a child in any suit to which he/she may be a party for the protection of the child's interest.
"Indian" is any member of a federally recognized tribe or a person eligible for membership in a federally recognized tribe.
"Indian Custodian" is an adult Indian to whom temporary physical care, custody and control has been transferred by the parent of such minor.
"Juvenile Offender" is a person who commits a delinquent act prior to their eighteenth (18th) birthday.

"Legal Custody" is a legal status created by a Court that vests in a person the right and duty to protect the custody of a minor, the right and duty to protect, train and discipline the minor and to provide him/her with food, shelter, education and ordinary medical care, all subject to the powers, rights, duties and responsibilities of the guardian of the minor and subject to any remaining parental rights and duties; an individual granted legal custody of a minor shall exercise his/her rights and responsibilities as custodian personally unless otherwise authorized by the Court entering the order.
"Minor" is a person under eighteen (18) years of age. "Minor-in-Need-of-Care" is a minor who is:

para.text: Neglected by a parent(s), guardian(s), Indian custodian(s), custodian(s) or other care-provider; or
Abused by a parent(s), guardian(s), Indian custodian(s), custodian(s) or other care-provider; or
A status offender.

section.text: "Neglect" occurs when a minor:

para.text: Has no parent(s), guardian(s), Indian custodian(s), custodian(s), or extended family member available and willing to care for him/her;

Has suffered, or is likely to certainly suffer a physical injury, inflicted upon him/her by other than accidental means, which causes or creates a substantial risk of death, disfigurement or impairment of bodily functions; or
Has not been provided with food, clothing, shelter, medical care, education or supervision adequate for his/her needs by his/her parent(s), guardian(s), Indian custodian(s) or custodian(s); or
Has committed delinquent acts as a result of parental pressure, guidance, or approval.

section.text: "Parent" includes a natural or adoptive parent but does not include persons whose parental rights have been terminated, nor does it include the unwed father whose paternity has not been acknowledged or established.

"Permanency Planning" is the procedure by which a permanent home is to be provided to every child, first, if possible, with the child(ren)'s parent(s) and, if that is not feasible within a reasonable time, with another person or family.
"Probable Cause" is reasonable cause or reasonable grounds to believe a fact, supported by sufficient evidence.

"Probation" is a legal status created by Court Order following an adjudication involving a violation of law by a minor, whereby the minor is permitted to remain in his/her home under prescribed conditions and under supervision of a probation officer, subject to return to the Court for further proceedings if any of the conditions prescribed are violated.

"Protective Supervision" is a legal status created by a Court Order in a proceeding not involving a delinquent act by a minor, whereby the minor is permitted to remain in his/her home under supervision and with assistance to correct the need for supervision or need of care which is provided by a social worker, probation officer or other agency designated by the Court.

"Restitution" is community service or financial reimbursement to the victim by the minor as ordered by the Court. It may include actual repairs done by the minor to the victim's damaged property. Financial reimbursement is limited to: actual damages for injury; loss of property; actual expenses for medical, psychiatric, and psychological treatment for injury to a person; and lost wages from physical injuries which are the direct result of the delinquent act.

"Shelter Care" is a home or living facility used as a temporary living place for a minor pending the return of the minor to his/her family or his/her placement in a residential facility designed for long-term placement.
"Status Offender" is a minor who:

para.text: Does not comply with the requirements of the compulsory school attendance Chapter of this Code; or
Disobeys, continually and habitually, the reasonable and lawful demands of his/her parent, guardian or custodian and is beyond parental control; or
Has left the home of his/her parent, guardian, or custodian without consent and has remained away for at least twenty-four (24) hours.

container.heading: STANDARDS FOR THE PROTECTION AND BENEFIT OF CHILDREN

section.heading: Best Interests of the Child.
section.text: All actions and decisions made under the authority of this Code shall be implemented to serve the best interests of the child. In determining the best interests of the child the following principles govern:

para.text: A child's need for love, nurturing, protection and stability. A child must have a safe and nurturing home environment offering emotional support and comfort; the basic needs of food, clothing and shelter; reasonable medical care and protection from danger, violence, or exposure to harmful conduct including drug and alcohol abuse.

A child's need for family. A child must have connection to loving and caring family members for guidance and nurturing. Although not all children have the benefit of family care, nothing can replace the primary role of loving parents and family in a child's life.

A child's need for identity and development. A child must develop self-identity and awareness of his/her unique role within the larger community, including the child's cultural community. This is done by participation in cultural activities, speaking one's native language and having opportunities and encouragement to pursue education and enrichment.

A child's need for happiness. A child cannot be happy unless his/her primary needs are met; but a child also needs opportunities for play and recreation, leisure time and other activities that the child enjoys, and possession of toys and other personal items of importance to the child.

Any placement under this Code shall be made for the best interests of the child(ren). All placement decisions should support the child(ren)'s affiliation with Pueblo of Picuris or Indian culture and provide the least restrictive environment which meets the child(ren)'s needs, and in the case of detention, assures the safety and protection of the public.

With the understanding that the prioritization must be interpreted with flexibility and recognizing that the best interests of the child(ren) are primary, the following order of priority shall guide all placements:
The child(ren) remain with the child(ren)'s family in the child(ren)'s home under conditions and restrictions established by the Court;
Placement in the home of an extended family member residing on the Pueblo of Picuris;
Placement in the home of an extended family member residing off the Pueblo of Picuris;
Placement in a facility or home outside the Pueblo of Picuris which is licensed or certified by the Tribe, or licensed or certified for such placement by the State of New Mexico.
The child(ren) shall be permitted to have appropriate involvement with family, tribal and cultural activities.

The Bureau of Indian Affairs Social Services Department, with the approval of the Tribal Council, shall adopt written regulations for the operation of a shelter care facility, foster care home, or detention facility licensed, certified, or approved by the Department. The regulations shall include standards for cleanliness, sanitation, heat, electricity, personnel, visiting privileges, occupancy limits, provisions for medical, dental and mental health care, and provisions for food, clothing and the possession of personal items.

The Department shall enforce the following standards and develop regulations consistent with such standards, for the treatment of minors in a shelter care facility, foster care home, or a detention facility:
A minor shall not be punished, ridiculed or criticized for expressing through speech, custom or dress in the minor's Indian or Tribal heritage;
Subject to legitimate institutional regulations, a minor shall be allowed to wear his/her hair as he/she chooses;
Incoming and outgoing mail may be inspected for contraband, but shall not be read;

Whenever possible, the minor shall be allowed to attend the school in which he/she is enrolled. If the circumstances do not permit the minor to attend his/her regular school, arrangements shall be made to permit the minor to continue his/her education;
A minor shall be allowed to attend family events and traditional ceremonies, provided that he/she is accompanied by a parent(s), guardian(s), Indian custodian(s), or custodian(s);
A minor shall be given the opportunity to engage in physical exercise for at least one hour every day;
A minor shall not be punished by physical force, solitary confinement, or deprivation of meals or family visits;

A minor shall perform reasonable work duties such as maintenance of his/her bed and personal property, but shall not be required to perform work duties not commensurate with his/her age, physical, mental, or emotional abilities.
In addition to and notwithstanding the provisions of Paragraph B, the following standards shall apply to any placement of a minor in a detention facility:
A minor shall wear only the clothing supplied by the detention facility;
If the minor is unable to attend a local school, schoolwork and education assistance at the minor's level of development shall be provided for the minor;

With prior Court Order, a minor shall be allowed to attend the funeral and related activities of family or extended family members, or to attend traditional ceremonies, provided that he/she is accompanied by the parent(s), guardian(s), Indian custodian(s), or custodian(s), and returns immediately to the detention facility at the conclusion of the period set by the Court.

If reasonable belief exists that a minor may cause physical injury to him/herself or others, he/she shall be placed in a supervised holding cell and monitored on a prescribed schedule and referred for immediate treatment by medical and/or psychological personnel.

section.heading: Duty to Report Abuse and Neglect.

para.text: Persons who have a reasonable cause to suspect a minor has been abused or neglected shall report the abuse or neglect to the Bureau of Indian Affairs Social Services Department and to the Bureau of Indian Affairs Law Enforcement Office.

Those persons who are required to report suspected abuse or neglect are any physician, nurse, other medical, mental health professional, principal, teacher, other school official, social worker, child care worker, other child care staff, including foster parents, residential care or institutional personnel, counselor, peace officer, judge, attorney, other judicial officer and any other person required to report pursuant to Federal or Tribal law. This paragraph shall not be interpreted to override ethical rules defining the attorney-client privilege.
Any person may make a report of suspected abuse or neglect.
Those persons reporting, except those specified in Paragraph B, may remain anonymous if the Court so determines.
All persons or agencies reporting abuse or neglect, in good faith, shall be immune from civil or criminal liability.

A record of all hearings under this Code shall be made and preserved until the jurisdiction of the Court has ended. All Court and law enforcement records concerning a minor shall be kept separate from the records of adults.
All records are confidential and shall not be open to inspection other than by Court personnel. The following persons are subject to regulations adopted by the Court:
The minor and his/her attorney;
The minor's parent(s), guardian(s), Indian custodian(s), or custodian(s);
The Juvenile Probation Officer or child welfare caseworker;
The prosecutor; and
Any other person granted permission by Court Order.
Each person who inspects a minor's record shall, in writing agree, to maintain the confidentiality of the record. Failure to abide by the agreement shall constitute Contempt of Court.

All records of a minor shall be sealed when the minor is no longer subject to the Court's jurisdiction, and thereafter, released only by Court Order following notice to the parties, and, only if needed, for a Court proceeding concerning a serious criminal charge or similar circumstance of compelling need. This paragraph shall not be construed to permit the release of information for other purposes, such as background checks conducted for employment, licensing, or security clearances. Adoption records shall be released as allowed in Section 10- 13-9.

section.heading: Confidentiality.
section.text: Any record or information obtained as a result of a proceeding covered by this Code and not otherwise covered by Section 10-2-5 are confidential and shall be made available only to his/her representative, the minor's parent(s), guardian(s), Indian custodian(s) or custodian(s), or to such other person the Court determines has valid reasons to see such records.

section.heading: Confidentiality of Detention.
section.text: The Court may order that the place of detention or shelter care be kept confidential to protect the best interests of the minor.

para.text: A minor may be fingerprinted or photographed without Court Order only under the following circumstances:
If necessary for identification;
To compare fingerprints found during an investigation, provided that a law enforcement officer has reasonable cause to believe the fingerprints are those of the minor; or
If there is reasonable cause to believe the minor has been subjected to abuse or neglect.
Copies of the fingerprints and photographs shall be immediately destroyed if the minor is not referred to the Court, unless needed for a criminal investigation.

section.heading: Full Faith and Credit.
section.text: The Court shall give full faith and credit to State (and other Tribes') child custody court orders, as defined by the Indian Child Welfare Act, 25 U.S.C. Section 1911 (d).

container.heading: ESTABLISHMENT OF THE PUEBLO OF PICURIS CHILDREN'S COURT

section.heading: Establishment.
section.text: There is hereby established for the Pueblo of Picuris, a Court to be known as the Pueblo of Picuris Children's Court.

para.text: The Pueblo of Picuris Tribal Court, when acting as a Children's Court, shall have the same powers and duties as the Tribal Court.
The Court is authorized to cooperate fully with federal, state, tribal, public, or private agencies in order to participate in any diversion, rehabilitation, or training programs.
The Court shall utilize such social services as may be furnished by any tribe, federal or state agency.
The Court shall accept or decline state court or other tribe's transfers of child custody proceedings as set out in the Code.
The Pueblo of Picuris Children's Court shall consist of one or more judges appointed by the Tribal Council.
In carrying out duties and powers specifically enumerated under the Children's Code, Judges of the Court shall have the same powers and duties as Judges of the Pueblo of Picuris Tribal Court.
The Court shall appoint a Children's Court Prosecutor who shall be responsible for carrying out the duties and responsibilities set forth in this Code.
The duties of the Children's Court Prosecutor are:
File petitions with the Court as provided in this Code;
Represents the interests of the Tribe in all proceedings under this Code; and
Perform such other duties as the Court may order.

The Court shall appoint from among the officers presently employed by the Eight Northern Pueblos Council Peacekeepers Program a Children's Court Juvenile Probation Officer who shall carry out the duties of this office.

The Juvenile Probation Officer shall not give any testimony in any court proceeding which may lead to the filing of juvenile offender charges against a minor but may testify for purposes of revoking probation.
The duties and powers of the Juvenile Probation Officer shall be to:
Make preliminary inquiries and social studies, and such other investigations as the Judge may direct and to keep written records of such investigations or studies;
Make reports as provided in this Code or as directed by the Judge;
Conduct informal adjustment hearings;
Place a minor in detention or shelter care as provided in this Code;
Identify and develop resources on the Pueblo of Picuris to enhance each minor's potential as a valuable member of the tribal community;

Explain to the minor, if old enough and to the parent(s), guardian(s), Indian custodian(s) or custodian(s), the meaning and conditions of probation or protective supervision and shall give necessary instructions;
Keep informed concerning the conduct and conditions of each minor on probation or under protective supervision and shall report thereon to the Judge as directed;
Use all suitable methods to aid minors on probation or under protective supervision to bring about improvements in their conduct or condition;
Perform such other duties in connection with the care, custody or transportation of children as the Court may require; and

Have the powers of law enforcement officers for purposes of this Code but shall, whenever possible, refrain from exercising such powers except in urgent situations in which a regular law enforcement officer is not immediately available.

section.heading: Clerk.
section.text: The Clerk of the Tribal Court shall act as Children's Court Clerk and shall keep a record of the court proceedings, issue all processes and notices required herein, and perform such other duties as may be assigned by the Judge.

para.text: The Court in any proceedings authorized by this Code may appoint, for the purpose of the proceedings, a guardian ad litem for a minor where the Court finds that the minor does not have a parent, guardian or custodian appearing on behalf of the minor or if the interest of the minor conflicts with the interest of the parent, guardian or custodian.
The guardian ad litem shall be familiar with the rights of children and the provisions of this Code.
Duties of the guardian ad litem are to:
Represent the minor's interest in any proceedings as required by this Court; and
Make recommendations to the Court on disposition.

section.heading: Court Appointed Special Advocates.
section.text: Pursuant to funding and guidelines by the Pueblo of Picuris the Court may utilize a Court Appointed Special Advocate (CASA) to assist in any Children's Court proceedings.

section.heading: Jurisdiction of the Pueblo of Picuris Children's Court.
section.text: The Children's Court of the Pueblo of Picuris has exclusive original jurisdiction of the following:

para.text: Juvenile offenders except in those cases transferred to Tribal Court pursuant to this Code;
Minors-in-need-of-care;
Termination of parental rights;
Adoption of minors;
Award of custody or appointment of custodian or guardian of minors;
Commitment of minors;
Emancipation;
Minors before a State court who are residents or domiciliary of the Tribe as required by the Indian Child Welfare Act, 25 U.S.C. Section 1911 (a);

Minors before a State court who are not residents or domiciliary of the Tribe and transfer of jurisdiction has been requested and accepted as required by the Indian Child Welfare Act, 25 U.S.C. Section 1911 (b); or
Adults as set out in this Code.

section.heading: Concurrent Jurisdiction.
section.text: The Children's Court of the Pueblo of Picuris has concurrent jurisdiction over any minor who commits an act, which is deemed illegal by federal, state, municipal or other tribe's law, while within any of those jurisdictions when that minor is an enrolled member of the Pueblo of Picuris.

section.heading: Transfer to Tribal Court of Alleged Juvenile Offender.

para.text: The prosecutor may file a petition requesting the Court to transfer the minor to the jurisdiction of the Tribal Court if the minor is at least sixteen (16) years of age and is alleged to have committed an act that would be considered a crime if committed by an adult.
The Court shall conduct a hearing within ten (10) days of filing of the petition to determine whether jurisdiction of the minor should be transferred to Tribal Court.
The Juvenile Probation Officer shall prepare and present a written report to the Court at least three (3) days before the transfer hearing. The report shall contain:
Information on the nature and seriousness of the alleged offense(s);
The nature and condition of the minor as evidenced by his/her age as well as mental and physical condition; and
Past record of offenses and Court efforts at rehabilitation

The prosecutor and other attorneys representing parties may also file with the Court written recommendations within the same time limit. All reports shall be served on all parties at the same time they are filed.
The following factors shall be considered by the Court when determining whether to transfer jurisdiction of the minor to Tribal Court:
The nature and seriousness of the offense(s) with which the minor is charged;
The nature and condition of the minor, as evidences by his/her age as well as mental and physical condition; and
The past record of offenses and Court efforts at rehabilitation.

The Court may transfer jurisdiction of the minor to Tribal Court if the Court finds clear and convincing evidence that there are no reasonable prospects for rehabilitating the minor through resources available to the Court and either of the following exist:
The past offenses allegedly committed by the minor indicate a pattern of conduct which constitutes a substantial danger to the public; or
The offense with which the minor is charged as a juvenile offender indicates conduct which constitutes substantial danger to the public.
The Court's Order under this Section is a final Order for the purposes of appeal.

section.heading: Transfer from State Court under the Indian Child Welfare Act (P.L. 95-608).

para.text: The Tribal agent for service of notice of State Court child custody proceedings, as defined by the Indian Child Welfare Act (ICWA), shall be the Pueblo of Picuris ICWA Director.

Investigation and pre-transfer report shall be done by the Bureau of Indian Affairs Social Services. The Bureau of Indian Affairs Social Services shall conduct an investigation and file a written report with the Court within three (3) days of receipt of notice from the Tribal agent for service of notice. The report shall include facts which will assist the Court in making its decisions as required by this Section, including but not limited to: parentage, family, existing relatives, reasons for minor being subject to Court jurisdiction, and, if transfer or intervention will be in the minor's best interest.
Decision for Transfer or Intervention: The Court shall determine whether the Tribe should petition for transfer from or intervene in State Court and shall file a written order to that effect.

Petition for Transfer or Intervention: The Pueblo of Picuris Indian Child Welfare Act (ICWA) Director shall file a petition for transfer or intervention, within three (3) days of the Pueblo of Picuris Tribal Court's Order.
The Court will not accept a transfer from State Court unless the Bureau of Indian Affairs Social Services report recommends acceptance of transfer, and if either of the following exist:
A parent of Indian custodian's petition to State Court for transfer is granted; or
The Tribe's petition to State Court for transfer is granted.

Adjudicatory Hearing: Upon receipt of transfer jurisdiction from State Court, the Indian Child Welfare Act (ICWA) Director shall file a minor-in-need-of-care petition, and an adjudicatory hearing shall be held in accordance with this Code.
Parental Responsibility.
Parent as Party: The parent of the child may be made a party to a petition if the child is alleged to be a minor-in-need-of-care or a juvenile offender.

Dispositions: The Court may order the parent to submit to counseling, participate in any probation or other treatment program ordered by the Court and, if the child is committed for institutionalization, to participate in any institutional treatment or counseling program including attendance at the site of the institution.
Fines: The parent is not liable for a fine his/her child may be ordered to pay.
Cost of Support: The Court shall order the parent to pay the reasonable cost or part of the cost of support and treatment of the child if:
The child is adjudicated a minor-in-need-of-care, or a juvenile offender; and
The Court orders this child placed with an agency, institution or an individual other than the parent.
Other Adults: The Court shall join as a party any adult necessary for proper disposition of any case heard pursuant to this Code.
Enforcement: The Court may enforce any orders issued under this Section by use of its contempt power.

section.heading: Continuance of Jurisdiction.
section.text: For dispositional purposes, jurisdiction over a child under this Children's Code shall continue until he/she becomes nineteen (19) years of age, unless such jurisdiction is terminated prior thereto.

section.heading: Rules of Procedure.
section.text: The Chief Judge, subject to the approval of the Tribal Council, may adopt rules of procedure and forms for the conduct of the Children's Court.

para.text: Petition: Except as otherwise provided below, proceedings in children's cases begin by a petition.

Exceptions to Petition: A petition shall not be required in the case of violations of motor vehicle laws, ordinances, or fish and game laws and ordinances. The issuance of a traffic or other citation or summons for these violations is sufficient to invoke the jurisdiction of the Children's Court. Unless the Court otherwise orders, a preliminary investigation is not required in such cases.
A petition shall be entitled, "In the Matter of , A Minor," and shall set forth:
The name, date of birth, and residence of the minor;
The names and residences of the minor's parent(s), guardian(s), or custodian(s);
A citation to the specific section, including number, of this Code, which gives the Court jurisdiction of the proceedings;
Where applicable, a citation to the section of the Criminal Code which the minor is alleged to have violated;
If the minor is in detention or shelter care, the place of detention or shelter care and the date and time he/she was taken into custody; and
A concise statement of facts.
Preparation: The statements in the petition may be made upon information and belief and the petition shall be prepared, verified and signed by a Bureau of Indian Affairs Law Enforcement Officer.
Dismissal: The Court may dismiss a petition at any stage of the proceedings.

When Required: After a petition is filed and after such further investigation as the Court may direct, the Court shall promptly issue a summons. No summons is required for any person who appears voluntarily or who files a written waiver of service with the Clerk of the Court at or prior to the hearing.

Content: The summons shall contain the name of the Court, the title of the proceedings, and (except for a published summons) a brief summary of the allegations in the petition. A published summons shall simply state that a proceeding concerning the child is pending in the Court and that adjudication will be made.

Who shall receive: The summons shall be served on all parties and the person or persons who have physical custody of the child requiring them to appear personally and to bring the child before the Court at a time and place stated. If the person or person so summoned are not the parent(s) or guardian of the child, then a summons shall also be served on the parent(s) or guardian(s) as the case may be, notifying them of the pendency of the case and of the time and place set for the hearing. No summons needs to be issued to a parent or parents whose parental rights have been terminated.

section.heading: Subpoena of Witnesses.
section.text: The Court shall issue a subpoena immediately upon a request of any party, but such request shall be made at least forty-eight (48) hours before any hearing for which a subpoena is requested.

section.heading: Manner of Service of Court Orders.

para.text: Who Serves Court Orders: Service of summons, subpoena or other Court Order shall be made by an officer of BIA Law Enforcement or the Pueblo of Picuris Tribal Sheriff; but upon request of the Court such service may be made by the Tribal Sheriff or by another suitable person selected by the Court.

Place of Service: Service of summons, subpoena or other Court Order on the Pueblo of Picuris may be made by delivering a copy thereof to the person summoned, subpoenaed or entitled to a copy of the Order; provided, however, that parents of a child living together in their home may both be served personally by delivering to either parent copies of the summons, one copy for each parent.

Service by Mail: If the Court is satisfied that personal service of the summons or order is impractical under the circumstances, the Court may order service by registered mail, with a return receipt requested to be signed by the addressee only, to be addressed at the last known address or the person to be served on the Pueblo of Picuris. Service shall be complete upon return to the Court of the signed receipt.

Other Service: If the parent or guardian of any minor required to be summoned by this Code cannot be found within the Pueblo of Picuris, the minor's presence within the Pueblo shall confer jurisdiction on the Court in proceedings in children's cases under this Code as to any absent parent(s), guardian(s), Indian custodian(s), or custodian(s) provided that due notice has been given in one of the following manners:

If the address of the parent or guardian is unknown, by sending him/her a copy of the summons by registered mail with return receipt requested to be signed by the addressee only, or by personal service outside the exterior boundaries of the Pueblo of Picuris. Service by registered mail shall be complete upon return to the Court of the signed receipt.

If the address or whereabouts of the guardian outside of the Pueblo, cannot, after diligent inquiry, be ascertained, by publishing a summons in a newspaper having general circulation on the Pueblo. The summons shall be published once a week for four (4) successive weeks. Service shall be complete on the day of the last publication. Proof of such service shall be filed with the Court.

Summons – In the case of service on the Pueblo of Picuris, service completed not less than five (5) days before the time set in the summons for the appearance of the person served, shall be sufficient to confer jurisdiction. In the case of service outside the Pueblo of Picuris, service completed not less than eight (8) days before the time set in the summons for appearance of the person served, shall be sufficient to confer jurisdiction.
Subpoenas and other Court orders shall be served not less than twenty-four (24) hours before the time set for the hearing.

Custodial Warrant: The Court may issue a warrant directing that a minor be taken into custody upon a sworn written statement of facts showing probable cause to believe the minor is a juvenile offender and is a danger to him/herself or to the community.

Emergency Custody Order: The Court may issue an emergency custody order upon a sworn written statement of facts showing probable cause to believe that a minor is a minor-in-need- of-care and is in immediate danger from his/her surroundings.
Search Warrants.

The Court may issue a warrant authorizing a law enforcement officer to search for a minor if there is probable cause to believe that the minor is within the Court's jurisdiction and a custodial warrant has been issued for the alleged juvenile offender or an Emergency Custody Order has been issued for a minor alleged to be a minor-in- need-of-care; or

The Court may issue a warrant authorizing a law enforcement officer to search for and seize property when probable cause has been established that the property has been obtained or is possessed in a manner, which constitutes a delinquent act; or is designed or intended for use or which is or has been used as a means of committing a delinquent act; or would be material evidence in a proceeding.
Bench Warrant: The Court may issue a warrant for a person's arrest for contempt of court immediately upon the failure to appear in court, either in person or by counsel, as ordered by the Court.

section.heading: Contempt of Court.
section.text: The Court may punish an adult for contempt of court in accordance with the Pueblo of Picuris Law and Order Code, but only after a hearing in which the defendant is accorded the procedures and rights required by this Code.

section.heading: Separate, Civil Proceedings.
section.text: Proceedings in children's cases shall be regarded as civil proceedings, with the Court exercising equitable powers. Children's cases shall be handled separately from adult cases.

para.text: Private and Closed: Hearings shall be separate from other proceedings and shall be private and closed to the public except hearings for traffic, hunting and fishing violations. Only the parties, their attorneys, witnesses and other persons requested by the parties and approved by the Court may be present at the hearing.
Denial of Allegations: If the allegations are denied, the Court shall hear the evidence and decide whether or not the allegations are true.
Admission of Allegations: The Court must find that an admission is voluntarily and knowingly made.

Informal, Non-Jury Hearing: All hearings shall be heard by the Court without a jury and may be conducted in an informal manner so long as the rights of every person appearing before the Court are protected as required by this Code.
Dismissal or Disposition.
The Court will dismiss the petition if the allegations are not established by the required standard of proof; or
The Court will proceed to the dispositional hearing if the allegations are established by a valid admission or by the required standard of proof.
Postponement: On the Court's motion, or the motion of the minor, his/her parent(s), guardian, custodian, or attorney, the Court may postpone the hearing for a reasonable time.

section.heading: Standard of Proof.
section.text: The standard of proof of a juvenile offender's adjudicatory hearing or for termination of parental rights shall be proof beyond a reasonable doubt, and for all other hearings, the standard of proof shall be clear and convincing evidence.

section.heading: Use of Reports in Minor-in-Need-of-Care and Dispositional Hearing.
section.text: For the purpose of establishing that a child is a minor-in-need-of-care, and for the purpose of determining proper disposition of a minor in any case, written reports and other materials relating to the child's mental, physical and social history and condition, may be received in evidence, and may be considered by the Court along with other evidence, but the Court may require that the person who wrote the report or prepared the material appear as a witness if he/she is reasonably available.

section.heading: Consolidation.
section.text: When more than one child is involved in the same situation which may be found to constitute abuse or neglect, or when more than one child is alleged to be involved in the same law violation, the proceedings may be consolidated, except that separate hearings may be held with respect to disposition.

section.heading: Amendment of Pleadings; Postponements.
section.text: When it appears, during the course of any proceeding in a child's case that the evidence presented alleges material facts not alleged in the petition, the Court may proceed to consider the additional or different matters raised by the evidence. In such event, the Court, on motion of any interested party or on its own motion, shall direct that the petition be amended to conform to the evidence. The Court shall grant such postponements as justice may require when a petition is amended under this Section.

section.heading: Special Rules of Procedure: Traffic, Fish and Game Laws and Violations.
section.text: The Court may adopt special rules of procedure to govern proceedings involving violations by children of traffic laws or ordinances, and violations of fish and game laws or ordinances.

section.heading: Presence of Parent, Guardian, Custodian, or Guardian Ad Litem.
section.text: The Court shall endeavor to insure the presence at a hearing of one or both parents or guardian or custodian of the minor. If no parent, guardian or custodian is present during the hearing, the Court shall appoint a guardian ad litem to protect the interests of the child.

section.heading: Grounds for Re-Hearing.
section.text: A parent, guardian or custodian of any child whose status has been adjudicated in a case under this Code, or any adult affected by an order or judgment in a proceeding under this Code, may at any time petition the Court for a new hearing on the grounds that new evidence, which was not known or could not, with due diligence, have been made available at the original hearing and which might affect the order or judgment, has been discovered. If it appears to the Court that there is such new evidence, which might affect its order or judgment, it shall order a new hearing and enter such order or judgment and make such disposition of the case as is warranted by all the facts and circumstances and the best interests of the child.

section.heading: Modification, Revocation or Extension of an Order.

para.text: The Court may modify, revoke, or extend an order at any time upon the motion of the following:
The minor and his/her attorney;
The minor's parent, guardian, or custodian;
The Juvenile Probation Officer; or
The Bureau of Indian Affairs Law Enforcement.
A hearing to modify, revoke, or extend a Court Order shall be conducted according to this Chapter.

section.heading: Judgment.
section.text: The Court shall file a written judgment including the findings, decision, and disposition of every minor and their party within five (5) days of the date of the disposition.

para.text: Computation: In calculating any period of time under this Code, the day of the act or event from which the period of time begins to run is not included, unless otherwise specifically provided by this Code or Court rules. The last day of the period so computed is included, unless it is a Saturday, Sunday or legal holiday, in which case the last day is the next business day. However, whenever a minor is taken into custody pursuant to this Code, the minor's parent, guardian or custodian shall be notified of his/her custody within the time limit set by this Code and such limit shall be computed by including Saturday, Sunday or legal holidays.

Failure to Comply with Time Limit: Failure to comply with time limits is not grounds for granting a new hearing or for setting aside a verdict, for vacating, modifying or otherwise disturbing a judgment or order or dismissing an action, unless refusal to take such action appears to the Court to work a substantial injustice or unless these rules expressly provide otherwise.

section.heading: Due Process Guaranteed.
section.text: All provisions and procedures of this Code shall be interpreted and applied to provide due process of law to both children and adults subject to the Children's Code.

section.heading: Custody Warnings.
section.text: At the time a minor is taken into custody, he/she shall be given the following warnings.

para.text: The minor has the right to remain silent;
Anything the minor says can be used against the minor in court;
The minor has a right to the presence of an attorney at his/her own expense during questioning; and
If he/she cannot afford an attorney, he/she may be eligible for any free legal services available on the Pueblo of Picuris.

section.heading: Questioning of Minor in Custody.
section.text: A minor alleged to be a juvenile offender who is taken into custody and placed in detention or shelter care shall not be questioned except in the presence of his/her parent, spokesperson, guardian ad litem, guardian, custodian, or attorney except to determine identity and immediate physical or medical needs. A minor who is at least sixteen (16) years of age may select the person who will be present during questioning.

section.heading: Right to an Attorney or Spokesperson.
section.text: Each party has the right to be represented by an attorney or spokesperson at his/her own expense at every stage of the proceedings.

section.heading: Right to Remain Silent.
section.text: Each party has the right to remain silent and not be forced to speak or testify at any stage of the proceedings but must appear as ordered by the Court.

section.heading: Right to Testify.
section.text: Each party has the right to speak or testify at an appropriate stage of the proceedings, but any statement made by him/her may be used against him/her during the proceedings.

section.heading: Right to Cross-Examine.
section.text: Each party has the right to question or cross-examine witnesses.

section.heading: Right to Subpoena and Present Witnesses.
section.text: Each party has the right to subpoena witnesses on his/her own behalf and have witnesses testify on his/her behalf.

section.heading: Notice.
section.text: The minor and his/her attorney and his/her parent, guardian or custodian and his/her attorney and any other party have the right to adequate notice of all proceedings.

section.heading: Appeal.
section.text: The minor and his/her attorney and his/her parent, guardian, custodian or any other party, have the right to appeal as set out in this Code.

section.heading: Fingerprints and Photographs.
section.text: An alleged juvenile offender shall not be fingerprinted or photographed without the consent of the Court as set out in this Code. An alleged minor-in-need-of-care may not be fingerprinted or photographed unless allegations of abuse or neglect have been made and in those cases, photographs may be taken.

section.heading: Guardian Ad Litem.
section.text: The Court, at any stage of a proceeding, shall appoint a guardian ad litem for a minor who is a party, if the minor has no parent, guardian or custodian appearing on their behalf, or if the interests of the minor conflict with the interests of the parent, guardian or custodian or when it appears to the Court that the child's best interest warrant the appointment.

section.heading: Consequences of Petition.
section.text: The Court shall inform all parties at the beginning of each hearing of the possible consequences if the allegations of the petition are found to be true.

section.heading: Admissibility of Evidence in Other Proceedings.
section.text: No adjudication upon a juvenile offender shall be deemed criminal or a conviction of a crime. Therefore, the disposition of a child or evidence given shall not be admissible as evidence against the child in any proceedings in another court.

para.text: Confidential Matters: All proceedings, records and information held pursuant to this Code are confidential as set out in this Code.
Contempt: Any person found to have violated the confidentiality of any minor's case or file shall be found in contempt of court.

section.heading: Confidentiality of Detention.
section.text: The Court may order, at any time, that the place of detention or shelter care be kept confidential in order to protect the best interests of the minor.

para.text: Required Investigations: The Court may require that an investigation be made and a report be submitted to the Court in writing on all cases under this Code in which a petition has been filed, except violations of traffic, and fish and game laws and ordinances. Investigations for juvenile offenders shall be submitted to the Court for dispositional purposes only and shall not be submitted until after adjudication is completed and the Court has found that the minor has committed the alleged acts.

Scope: The investigation shall cover the child's home environment, history and present condition of the child and family, and recommendations as to the child's future care. In cases involving the duty of support, the study shall include such matters as earnings, assets, financial obligations and employment.

section.heading: Taking a Minor into Custody.
section.text: Law enforcement officers may take a minor into custody if:

para.text: The officer has reasonable grounds to believe a delinquent act has been committed in his/her presence and that the minor has committed the delinquent act; or
A warrant pursuant to this Code has been issued for the minor; or
The officer has reasonable cause to believe a minor who is subject to the Children's Code jurisdiction is leaving the jurisdiction of the Court.
Review and Signature on Complaint: The complaint shall be on a form authorized pursuant to the order of the Tribal Court. It shall state:
The specific sections which give the Court jurisdiction; and
The Code provision, which is alleged to have been violated; and
The name, age and address of the minor who is subject to the complaint; and
Any parties to the allegations; and
The facts upon which the allegations are based, including the date, time, and location at which the alleged facts occurred; and
If the child is in detention or shelter care, the time and date placed in such care and the reasons therefore.

section.heading: Warrants.
section.text: Warrants shall be issued in accordance with Chapter 5 of this Code.

para.text: A law enforcement officer taking a minor into custody shall:
Give the warnings required by this Code to any minor he/she takes into custody prior to any questioning; and
Release, immediately, the minor to the minor's parent, guardian or custodian and issue verbal counsel or warning as may be appropriate; or

Deliver, immediately, the minor to the detention or shelter care as designated by the Court, or to a medical facility if the minor is believed to need prompt medical treatment. All notifications required by this Section shall be made directly to the Court, notwithstanding weekends or holidays.
The Bureau of Indian Affairs Law Enforcement, immediately upon delivery of the minor into custody or notification of custody, shall review the need for detention or shelter care and shall:
Notify immediately the parent, guardian, or custodian notwithstanding the fact that custody was taken during the weekend or holidays;
Release the minor to his/her parent, guardian or custodian unless detention or shelter care is appropriate pursuant to this Section; and

In all cases, the minor shall be released to his/her parent, guardian, or custodian within seventy-two (72) hours of the time taken into custody unless the Court issues its order requiring the custody continue.
A minor may not be released if:
A Court Order forbids release;
It appears that the minor is in immediate danger of physical harm; or
Reasonable cause exists to believe that the minor will run away from the Pueblo of Picuris and its boundaries.

section.heading: Delivery of Minor to Detention or Shelter Care.
section.text: If a minor's parent, guardian or custodian cannot be found, and if there is no relative to whom the minor may be released, or if circumstances pursuant to Section 10-9-4C of this Code arise, the minor shall be delivered to a place of detention or shelter care designated by the Court. The Indian Child Welfare Act (ICWA) Director shall immediately make arrangements for the temporary care and custody of the minor.

para.text: The purpose of the preliminary inquiry is to determine the best interest of the minor with regard to any action to be taken. In determining the best interest of the minor, the Court shall examine whether probable cause exists to believe the alleged act was committed and whether continued detention or shelter care is necessary pending further proceedings.
Time Limits.
Minor in Custody: The preliminary inquiry shall be held within seventy-two (72) hours of the beginning of the time of detention or shelter care.
Minor Released from Custody: The preliminary inquiry shall be held within three (3) days of release of the minor from detention or shelter care.
Minor Never in Custody: The preliminary inquiry shall be held within ten (10) days of the filing of a complaint.

Presence of Minor's Parents or Guardian: If the minor's parent(s) or guardian is not present at the preliminary inquiry, the Court shall determine what efforts have been made to notify and to obtain the presence of the parent(s) or guardian. If it appears that further efforts are likely to produce the parent(s) or guardian, the Court shall recess for not more than twenty-four (24) hours and direct the Bureau of Indian Affairs Law Enforcement or Pueblo of Picuris Tribal Sheriff to make continued efforts to obtain the presence of a parent, guardian, or custodian.

Dismissal of Complaint and Release of a Minor: If the Court determines that there is no probable cause to believe that the minor has committed the alleged act, the complaint shall be dismissed without prejudice and the minor is to be released.

Release from Custody: If the Court determines that there is probable cause to believe that the minor has committed the alleged act and that the minor is not in need of detention or shelter care, the minor shall be released to the custody of his/her parent(s) or guardian pending final disposition of the matter. Otherwise, the minor shall continue to be held in custody until further order of the Court.

Criteria for Detention or Shelter Care: The Court may order detention or shelter care, or order it to continue, if the Court finds probable cause exists to believe the minor committed the alleged act and:
The act is serious enough to warrant continued detention or shelter care; or
There is reasonable cause to believe the minor will run away so that he/she will be unavailable for further proceedings; or
There is reasonable cause to believe that the minor will commit a serious act causing damage to person or property.

Plea and Disposition: A minor may admit or deny that he/she committed the alleged illegal act at the preliminary inquiry. If the minor denies committing the act, the Court shall proceed as directed in this Code. If the minor wishes to admit he/she committed the alleged act, the Court must first determine that:
The minor has a full understanding of his/her rights under this Code; and
The minor has full understanding of the consequences of admitting that he/she committed the alleged act; and

The minor has not stated any facts that would be a defense. If the Court determines that the minor does not understand his/her rights or the consequences of admitting to have committed the alleged act or the minor has stated a defense, the Court shall order either an informal adjustment conference be held or that a petition be filed. If the Court determines that the minor understands his/her rights and the consequences of admitting to having committed the alleged act and has not stated a defense, the Court may proceed to the dispositional hearing as allowed by this Code.
Place of Detention: A minor alleged to be a juvenile offender may be detained, pending a court hearing, in one of the following:
A foster care facility on the Pueblo of Picuris;
A detention facility on contract with the Bureau of Indian Affairs;
A private family home on the Pueblo of Picuris; or
A facility outside of the Pueblo of Picuris which has been approved by the State of New Mexico.

section.heading: Petition.
section.text: The petition shall be prepared as required by this Code and filed within three (3) days after it is determined or recommended that a petition be filed unless an extension of time is filed with the Pueblo of Picuris Tribal Court.

section.heading: Notice of Hearing.
section.text: A notice of hearing shall be given to all parties as required by this Code.

section.heading: Summons.
section.text: A summons shall be issued and served as required by this Code.

para.text: Time Limit: A hearing on the petition shall be held within ten (10) days after the petition is filed.
Purpose: The Court shall conduct the hearing for the primary purpose of determining if a minor committed the alleged illegal act.
Plea: If the minor wishes to admit that he/she has committed the alleged illegal act, the Court shall proceed as required in Section 10-9-6G of this Code.

Disposition: If the Court finds that the minor committed the alleged illegal act, the Court shall dispose of the matter in a manner least restrictive for the minor and consistent with the best interests of the minor and the Tribe as allowed in Chapter 11 of this Code.
Final Order: A finding that the minor is a juvenile offender is a final order.

section.heading: Probation Revocation Hearing.
section.text: A minor who is alleged to have violated his/her terms of probation may be proceeded against in a probation revocation hearing. All procedures, rights and duties applicable to juvenile offender petitions shall be followed in a probation revocation hearing.

para.text: Law Enforcement Officer.
A law enforcement officer shall take a minor into custody if:
He/she has reasonable grounds to believe that the minor is a minor-in-need-of-care and that the minor is in immediate danger from his/her surroundings and that his/her removal is necessary; or
An Emergency Custody Order has been issued for the minor; or
He/she has reasonable causes to believe that a minor who is subject to the Children's Court jurisdiction is leaving the jurisdiction of the Court.
Law Enforcement Officer: A law enforcement officer taking a minor into custody shall:
Release the minor, immediately, to the minor's parent(s), guardian or custodian and issue a verbal counsel or warning as may be appropriate; or

Deliver the minor, immediately, to the child welfare caseworker, or to shelter care as designated by the Court, or to a medical facility if the minor is believed to need prompt medical treatment. If the minor is not delivered to the caseworker, the officer shall immediately notify the caseworker of the circumstances of the custody and location of the minor.
Who Shall Sign: The Bureau of Indian Affairs Law Enforcement shall review and investigate all complaints.
Form and Content: The form shall be on a form authorized pursuant to the order of the Tribal Court. It shall state:
The specific sections which gives the Court jurisdiction; and
The Code provision, which is alleged to have been violated; and
The name, age and address of the minor who is subject to the complaint; and
Any parties to the allegations; and
The facts upon which the allegations are based, including the date, time, and location at which the alleged facts occurred; and
If the minor is in detention or shelter care, the time and date placed in such care and the reasons therefore.

section.heading: Warrants and Custody Orders.
section.text: Warrants and custodial orders shall be issued in accordance with this Code.

para.text: Purpose: The purpose of the preliminary inquiry is to determine the best interest of the minor and the tribe with regard to any action to be taken. In determining the best interests of the minor, the Court shall examine whether probable cause exists to believe the alleged act, abuse, or neglect was committed and whether continued shelter care is necessary pending further proceedings.
Time Limits.
Minor in Custody: The preliminary inquiry shall be held within seventy-two (72) hours of the beginning of the time of detention or shelter care.
Minor Released from Custody: The preliminary inquiry shall be held within three (3) days of release of the minor from detention or shelter care.
Minor Never in Custody: The preliminary inquiry shall be held within ten (10) days of the filing of a compliant.

Presence of the Minor's Parent(s) or Guardian: If the minor's parent(s) or guardian is not present at the preliminary inquiry, the Court shall determine what efforts have been made to notify and to obtain the presence of the parent(s) or guardian. If it appears that further efforts are likely to produce the parent(s) or guardian, the Court shall recess for not more than twenty-four (24) hours and direct the Bureau of Indian Affairs Law Enforcement or Pueblo of Picuris Tribal Sheriff to make continued efforts to obtain the presence of a parent(s) or guardian.

Dismissal of Complaint and Release of Minor: If the Court determines that there is no probable cause to believe that the minor is a minor-in-need-of-care, the complaint shall be dismissed without prejudice and the minor released.

Release from Custody: If the Court determines that there is a probable cause to believe that the minor is a minor-in-need-of-care, but the minor is not in need of shelter care, the minor shall be released to the custody of his/her parent(s) or guardian pending final disposition of the matter and under protective supervision.

section.heading: Necessity of Custody and Shelter Care.
section.text: Custody and shelter care are needed if the Court finds probable cause exists to believe the minor is a minor-in-need-of-care and one or more of the following also exists;

para.text: The minor is suffering from an illness or injury, and no parent(s) or guardian, or other person is providing adequate care for him/her;
The minor is in immediate danger from his/her surroundings, and removal is necessary for his/her safety or well-being;
The minor will be subject to injury by others or by him/herself if not placed in the custody of the Court;
The minor has been abandoned by his/her parent(s) or guardian;
No parent(s) or guardian, or other person is able or willing to provide adequate supervision and care for the minor; and
The minor will run away and be unavailable for further proceedings.
Places Allowed: A minor alleged to be a minor-in-need-of-care may be detained pending a court hearing in the following places:
A foster care facility on the Pueblo of Picuris;
A private family home on the Pueblo of Picuris; or
A shelter care facility or an approved private family home outside of the Pueblo of Picuris.
Places Not Allowed: A minor who is alleged to be a minor-in-need-of-care may not be detained in a detention facility or jail.

section.heading: Investigation and Recommendations by the Indian Child Welfare Act Department.

para.text: Investigation: The Bureau of Indian Affairs Law Enforcement and/or the Indian Child Welfare Act (ICWA) Director shall investigate within forty-eight (48) hours of the preliminary inquiry or release of the minor to determine whether the interests of the minor require that further action be taken.
Recommendation: Upon completion of the investigation, the Bureau of Indian Affairs Law Enforcement or the Indian Child Welfare Act (ICWA) Director shall recommend to the Court:
No further action to be taken;
An informal adjustment conference; or
A petition to be filed.

section.heading: Petition Not Recommended; Release of Minor.
section.text: If the prosecutor does not file a petition, the minor shall be released immediately, if in shelter care, all charges shall be dismissed unless informal adjustment is recommended in which case the matter shall proceed as required by this Code.

para.text: Time Limit: An adjudicatory hearing shall be held within ten (10) days after the petition is filed.
Purpose: The Court shall conduct the hearing for the sole purpose of determining if a minor is a minor-in-need-of-care.
Final Order: A finding that a minor is a minor-in-need-of-care is a final order.

Disposition: If the Court finds that the minor is a minor-in-need-of-care, the Court shall dispose of the matter in a manner least restrictive to the minor consistent with the best interests of the minor.

section.heading: Minor-in-Need-of-Care; Dispositions.
section.text: If a minor has been adjudged a minor-in-need-of-care, the Court may make any of the following dispositions, which are listed by priority:

para.text: Permit the minor to remain with his/her parent(s) or guardian subject to such limitations and conditions as the Court may prescribe;
Place the minor with an extended family member within the Pueblo of Picuris, subject to such limitations and conditions as the Court may prescribe;
Place the minor in a Pueblo of Picuris member's foster home within the exterior boundaries of the Pueblo of Picuris;
Place the minor in another Pueblo of Picuris member's home, or if not available, another Tribe's member's home, within the exterior boundaries of the Pueblo of Picuris;
Place the minor in a residential facility under protective supervision as designated by the Court;

Place the minor in an extended family member's home outside the boundaries of the Pueblo of Picuris subject to such limitations and conditions as the Court may prescribe or if not available, in another Pueblo of Picuris member's home, or if not available another Tribe's member's home under the same circumstances.
Recommend that termination proceedings begin; or
Recommend that either full or partial emancipation be ordered.

section.heading: Juvenile Offender; Dispositions.
section.text: If a minor has been adjudicated as a juvenile offender, the Court may make any or all of the following dispositions:

para.text: Any disposition that is authorized for the disposition of a minor-in-need-of-care;
Place the minor on probation subject to conditions set by the Court;
Place the minor in an institution or with an agency designated by the Court; or
Place the minor in a detention facility; and
Require the minor to make restitution; and

In cases of violations of traffic laws or ordinances, the Court may in addition to any other disposition, restrain the child from driving for such period of time as the Court deems necessary, and may take possession of the child's driver's license.

section.heading: Conditions Set by Court.
section.text: The conditions or limitations which the Court may set upon a child, his/her parent(s) or guardian, or any other party pursuant to this Code shall be designed to improve the condition of the child if he/she is found to be a minor-in-need-of-care or the behavior of the child, if he/she is found to be a juvenile offender. Such conditions or limitations include, but are not limited to:

para.text: Counseling and/or therapy;
Restriction on visits with one or both parents;
Payment of support or other necessary costs;
Attendance at school;
Participate in Tribal sponsored activities;
Placement of restrictions on associations;
Curfew;
Any other dispositions as set out in this Code.

section.heading: Off-Pueblo of Picuris Agreements.
section.text: Whenever a minor is placed in a home or facility located outside the boundaries of the Pueblo of Picuris, the Court shall require the party receiving custody of the minor to sign an agreement that the minor will be returned to the Court upon order of the Court. Absent such a signed agreement, any person or institution shall be deemed to have consented to return such child by having taken placement under this Code.

section.heading: Probation Revocation.
section.text: If the Court finds that a minor has violated the terms of his/her probation, the Court may:

para.text: Extend the period of probation; or
Make a disposition that would have been appropriate in the original disposition.
Review: Dispositional orders are to be reviewed at the Court's discretion, but at least every six (6) months.

Discretionary Review: An interested party may ask the Court for a review of disposition at any time. The granting of such a request is done at the discretion of the Court and within the Court's jurisdiction.

section.heading: Final Order.
section.text: A dispositional order is a final order for purposes of appeal.

container.heading: REQUIREMENTS FOR REMOVAL OF MINOR FROM HOME.

section.heading: Removal of Minor from Home; Requirements
section.text: The removal of a minor from his/her home for foster care placement, termination of parental rights and pre-adoption placement must result from a judicial determination that continuation would be contrary to the welfare of each minor. Reasonable efforts are to be made before foster care placement, termination of parental rights and pre-adoption placement to prevent or eliminate the need to remove the minor from his/her home and reasonable efforts are to be made for the minor's return to his/her home and removal is in the best interest of the minor. Nothing in this Section prevents the emergency removal of a minor as allowed by the Children's Code, pursuant to Section 10-10-1.

section.heading: Periodic Review of Placement; Periodic Review.
section.text: Within six (6) months of the original disposition hearing and every three (3) months thereafter so long as the minor remains in foster care, the status of a minor will be reviewed upon recommendations made as a result of administrative review by the Court to:

para.text: Determine the continuing need for and appropriateness of the placement;
Determine the extent of compliance with the case plan;
Determine the extent of progress made toward easing or lessening the cause requiring the placement in foster care; and
Project a likely date by which the minor may be returned home or placed for adoption or legal guardianship.

section.heading: Permanency Planning Hearing; Disposition.
section.text: Within twelve (12) months of the original placement and every three (3) months thereafter, the Court shall hold a permanency planning hearing in accordance with the Children's Code to determine the future status of the minor. Recommendations made as a result of the administrative review shall be presented to the Court at this hearing and the Court shall adopt the recommendations unless good cause to the contrary is shown. The permanency planning hearing may be combined with the periodic review. The Court may order, but is not limited to, any of the following dispositions:

para.text: Returning the minor to the parent(s);
Ordering that a guardian be appointed and placing the child with the guardian;
Continuing the minor in foster care for a specific period;
Continuing the minor in foster care on a permanent or long term basis; and
Recommending parental rights be terminated and the minor placed for adoption.

section.heading: Procedures for Review Hearings.
section.text: The Court shall return a minor to the physical custody of his/her parent(s) or guardian, unless by a preponderance of evidence, it finds that returning the minor would cause a substantial risk to the physical or emotional well-being of the minor. The Behavioral Health has the burden of providing the risk. The Court shall review the Human Services and Administrative Review Panel reports, and consider any other evidence and testimony including the parent(s) or guardian treatment or efforts at rehabilitation. The Court also may order additional services, which will facilitate the return of the minor to the custody of his/her parent(s) or guardian.

section.heading: Periodic Reviews after Permanency Planning Hearing.

para.text: Periodic reviews conducted by the Court after the initial permanency planning hearing shall determine:
The appropriateness of the placement;
The continuing appropriateness, and extent of compliance with the permanent plan for the minor;
The extent of compliance with the case plan; and
Adequacy of services provided to the minor.
By the end of the sixth (6th) month of foster care, a decision regarding the permanent placement of the minor shall be made.

section.heading: Permanency Planning Hearing: When not Required.
section.text: Subsequent permanency planning hearings need not be held if:

para.text: The minor has been adopted; or
The minor is a ward of the Pueblo of Picuris Tribal Court.

section.heading: Notice of Change in Minor's Placement.
section.text: The removal of the minor from the parent(s) home, change of the minor's placement or a determination affecting a parent's visitation privileges may not be made without a notice to and an opportunity to be heard by the parent except if the Court determines that it would be in the minor's best interests to do.

section.heading: Bureau of Indian Affairs Human Services Department's Duties for Permanent Placements; Reports and Recommendations.

para.text: Duties: The Bureau of Indian Affairs Social Services Department is responsible for permanent placement of each minor in substitute or foster care. In order to achieve permanent placement as required by this Code, the Department is to prepare recommendations for the Administrative Review Panel and provide the recommendations to the panel members, the minor and his/her representative, parent(s), guardian or custodian, any other person or entity ordered by the Administrative Review Panel at least five (5) days before the permanency planning hearing and at least two (2) working days before each periodic review.

Reports and Recommendations: Each report shall first recommend whether or not the minor should be immediately returned to his/her parent(s) or guardian. If the Department recommends against such return, the report should address whether there is a substantial probability that the minor will be returned to the physical custody of his/her parent(s) or guardian within a reasonable time. If the report is being prepared for a permanency planning hearing and the Department determines there is substantial probability that the minor cannot be returned to his/her parent(s) or guardian within six (6) months, the report should address other permanent placement including long term foster care, guardianship, termination of parental rights and adoption.

section.heading: Confidentiality of Records of Bureau of Indian Affairs Social Services Department.
section.text: All BIA Social Services Department records shall be confidential and may be open only to:

para.text: Social Services personnel;
Tribal Court personnel.

section.heading: Purpose.
section.text: The purpose of this Chapter is to provide for voluntary or non-voluntary termination of the parent-child relationship by Court Order. Non-voluntary termination of parental rights over a child is a serious matter and an action that the Court may take only after all remedies have been exhausted in the attempt to maintain the stability of the family. Further, it is the purpose of this Chapter to provide meaningful and clear standards to be applied to cases involving termination of parental rights and to ensure competent, stable and on-going care of the child by prompt and final adjudication.

section.heading: Enrollment and Inheritance Status.
section.text: No adjudication of termination of parental rights shall affect a child's enrollment status as a member of the Pueblo of Picuris or a child's degree of blood quantum or a child's rights of inheritance from his/her natural parents so long as the child has not been adopted.

para.text: Termination Allowed: The Court may terminate a parent's rights when the Court finds beyond a reasonable doubt that the parent is: (1) unfit; (2) that the conduct or condition of the parent is such as to render him/her unable to care for the child and that such conduct or condition is unlikely to change within one year.
Factors to be considered: In determining unfitness, conduct, or condition, the Court shall consider, but is not limited to, any of the following:
The parent has abandoned the minor; or

Emotional illness, mental illness or mental deficiency of the parent of such duration or nature as to render the parent unable to care for the ongoing physical, mental and emotional needs of the child within one (1) year from the date of determination of illness; or
Abuse or neglect of the minor as defined by this Code; or
Excessive use of intoxicating liquors or illegal substances or drugs over a period of one or more years; or
Imprisonment of a single parent for a period of one or more years; or
Adjudication by a court or a plea of guilty by a parent to the charge that the parent, either intentionally or recklessly, willfully or wantonly caused the death or injury of a minor's sibling; or
Failure of the parent to provide a home or reasonable substitute physical care and maintenance where custody is lodged with others; or
Failure of the parent to maintain regular visitation or other contact with the child as designated in a plan to reunite the child with the parent; or
Failure of the parent to maintain consistent contact or communication with the child over a period of one year; or
Rehabilitation of the parent has been unsuccessful.

Parent Unknown: The rights of the parent may be terminated, as provided herein, if the Court finds that the child has been left under such circumstances that the identity of the parent is unknown and cannot be ascertained, despite diligent searching, and the parent has not come forward to claim the child within three (3) months following the finding of the child.

Best Interests of the Child: In considering terminating the rights of a parent, the Court shall give primary consideration to the best interests of the child as shown by his/her physical, mental, and emotional condition and needs.

section.heading: Petition.
section.text: The petition shall be prepared as required by this Code.

section.heading: Notice of Hearing.
section.text: Notice of Hearing shall be given to all parties as required by this Code.

para.text: Time Limit: The Indian Child Welfare Act (ICWA) Director shall prepare and present a written report to the Court at least ten (10) days before the Termination of Parental Rights hearing.

Content: The report shall contain the opinions of all professionals consulted with making recommendations to the Court and the social history of the parent(s) and the child(ren) and all other pertinent facts.
