Copies: A copy shall be available to the parent(s) whose rights were terminated at least ten (10) days before the hearing.
Additional Reports:
A parent whose parental rights are being terminated may also file a written report. A copy shall be made available to the prosecutor at the same time the report is filed.

The Court may also order other individuals or agencies to submit written reports. All reports shall be filed ten (10) days prior to the hearing and shall be made available to the parent whose rights are being terminated at the same time they are filed.

section.heading: Appointment of Counsel or Guardian Ad Litem.
section.text: In any proceeding for non-voluntary termination of parental rights, or any rehearing or appeal thereon, the Court shall appoint an advocate to represent the child as his/her counsel or guardian ad litem. The Court may appoint a guardian ad litem in a voluntary termination or parental rights proceeding.

para.text: Time Limit and Purpose: A Termination of Parental Rights hearing shall be held within thirty (30) days after a petition is filed for the purpose of determining whether grounds for termination exist as set out in this Code.

Witnesses: The Court shall subpoena experts who have knowledge of the particular case, including physicians, psychiatrists, mental health professionals, social workers, and any individual from the community cognizant of the traditional child-rearing methods and attitudes of the Tribe. The Court may subpoena the presence of any witnesses or persons who the Court finds have a direct interest in the case.
Conduct: The hearing shall be conducted in accordance with this Code.

section.heading: Judgment.
section.text: If parental rights to a child are terminated, the Court shall issue its judgment detailing its decision and the reasons for the decision and ordering the disposition of the minor as follows:

para.text: Place the minor with an extended family member; or
Place the minor in a foster care or shelter care facility, which has been approved by the Tribal Council; and in either case
Proceed to the Adoption Section of this Code.

section.heading: Appeal.
section.text: A judgment of non-voluntary termination of parental rights is a final order for purpose of appeal. An appeal must be filed within six (6) months from the date the termination order becomes final.

Parent Unknown: The rights of the parent(s) may be terminated as provided herein if the Court finds that the child has left under circumstances that the identity of the parent is unknown and cannot be ascertained, despite diligent searching, and the parent has not come forward to claim the child within three (3) months following the finding of the child.

Best Interests of the child(ren): In considering terminating the rights of a parent(s), the Court shall give primary consideration to the best interests of the child(ren) as shown by his/her physical, mental, and emotional condition and needs.

section.text: The petition shall be prepared as required by this Code.

section.heading: Notice of Hearing.
section.text: Notice of hearing shall be given to all parties as required by this Code.

para.text: Time Limit: The Indian Child Welfare Act (ICWA) Director shall prepare and present a written report to the Court at least 10 days before the termination of parental rights hearing.
Content: The report shall contain the opinions of all professionals consulted with recommendations to the Court and the social history of the parent and child and all other pertinent facts.
Copies: A copy shall be available to the parent whose rights are being terminated at least 10 days before the hearing.
Additional Reports
A parent whose rights are being terminated may also file a written report. A copy shall be made available to the prosecutor at the same time it is filed.

The Court may also order other individuals or agencies to submit written reports. All reports shall be filed 10 days prior to the hearing and shall be made available to the parent whose rights are being terminated at the same time they are filed.

section.heading: Appointment of Counsel or Guardian Ad Litem.
section.text: In any proceeding for non-voluntary termination of parental rights, or any rehearing or appeal thereon, the Court shall appoint an advocate to represent the child as his counsel or guardian ad litem. The Court may appoint a guardian ad litem in a voluntary termination or parental rights proceeding.

para.text: Time Limit; Purpose: A termination of parental rights hearing shall be held within 30 days after a petition is filed for the purpose of determining whether grounds for termination exist as set out in this Code.

Witnesses: The Court shall subpoena experts who have knowledge of the particular case, including physicians, psychiatrists, mental professionals, social workers, and any individual from the community cognizant of the traditional child-rearing methods and attitudes of the Tribe. The Court may subpoena the presence of any other witnesses or person who the Courtfinds have a direct interest in the case. If the proposed witnesses are not subject to tribal subpoena, the Court may request that they appear and testify.
Conduct: The hearing shall be conducted in accordance with this Code.

section.heading: Judgment.
section.text: If the parental rights to a child are terminated, the Court shall issue its judgment detailing its decision and the reasons for the decision and ordering the disposition of the minor as follows:

para.text: Place the minor with an extended family member; or
Place the minor in a foster care or shelter care facility, which has been approved by the Tribe; and in either case.
Proceed to the Adoption Section of the Code.

section.heading: Appeal.
section.text: A judgment of non-voluntary termination of parental rights is a final order for the purpose of appeal.

para.text: Initial Procedures: The Court may terminate parental rights when the parent desires to voluntarily give up such rights. In assuming jurisdiction of a voluntary termination of parental rights proceeding, the Court shall require that:
No voluntary termination shall occur before a child is ten (10) days old;

No voluntary termination shall occur until a written report is submitted to the Court by a Tribally recognized social services agency indicating that social services and counseling have been offered to the parent, that the consequences of the parent's actions have been fully explained and are understood by the parent, and that such action is in the best interest of the child; or

A parent may waive in writing, before a Judge of the Court, his/her right to appear at a hearing or the right to notice of hearing, or both, and the Court shall assure that such waiver is knowing and voluntary.

Counseling: In any proceeding for voluntary termination of parental rights, if the Court has reasonable doubt as to the emotional state of mind of the petitioner/parent or as to the petitioner's ability to understand the consequences of his/her decision, the Court shall place the child with extended family or foster care on the Pueblo of Picuris, for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days in order to allow the parent to consider his/her decisions. Further, the Court shall order legal and psychological counseling for the parent in order to assure his/her understanding of the consequences of his/her decision and a report of the results of such counseling shall be made to the Court.
Procedures After Counseling: Immediately after the end of the thirty (30) day period, the Court shall, based on the report submitted:
Return custody of the child to the parent;
Process the petition for voluntary termination of parental rights; or

Extend the period for no more than thirty (30) days to allow additional counseling. At the expiration of the additional counseling, and based upon the reports about the results of the counseling, the Court shall proceed as allowed by this Code.

section.heading: Interpreter for the Voluntary Termination of Parental Rights and Consent to Adoption.
section.text: A parent(s) who elects to voluntarily terminate his/her parental rights or consents to adoption shall be provided an interpreter if he/she does not understand English. A hearing to determine whether a non-English speaking parent is knowingly and voluntarily terminating his/her parental rights or consenting to adoption may be conducted by telephone if a local interpreter is not available.

section.heading: Who May Adopt and Under What Conditions.

para.text: The following persons may adopt:
Any adult may file a petition to adopt;

In the case of married persons maintaining a home together, both spouses shall be petitioners except that, if one spouse is the natural parent of the minor to be adopted, the natural parent shall not be a party to the petition;
A married person, legally separated, may adopt without the consent of his/her spouse.
Conditions to Adoption.
The welfare of the child shall be primary;
A person adopting shall be at least ten (10) years older than the minor;
Preference in adoption shall be given in the following order:
Extended family members;
Pueblo of Picuris adoptive parents;
Members of another Pueblo;
Any other Indian adoptive parents.

section.heading: Who May be Adopted.
section.text: A minor subject to the jurisdiction of the Pueblo of Picuris Tribal Court may be adopted under this Code.

section.heading: Petition.
section.text: A petition for adoption shall be filed with the Court. It shall be verified under oath by the petitioning party and shall contain:

para.text: The full name, residence and place of birth, date, and sex of the child, with attached documentary proof of the date and place of birth of the child to be adopted;
Documentary proof of the child's enrollment with the Tribe;

The full name, residence, date and place of birth, occupation of the petitioning party, statement of relationship to child, with attached documentary proof of their marital status, provided that this not be interpreted to prohibit single parent adoptions;

Proof of parental consent to the adoption where the petitioners are relatives of the child either by blood or affinity, except in cases where the natural parents have abandoned the child and cannot be located. In cases where there is documentary proof of a court order terminating the parent-child relationship with respect to each living parent of the child to be adopted;
An agreement by the adopting parent that it is his/her desire that the relationship of parent and child be established between them and the child;
A full description and statement of value of all property owned, possessed or held in trust by and for the child;
A citation to the specific Section, including number of this Code which gives the Court jurisdiction of the proceedings; and
A brief and concise statement of the facts, which may aid the Court in its determination.

The Indian Child Welfare Act (ICWA) Director: The child welfare caseworker shall prepare and present to the Court a report within sixty (60) days of the filing of a petition for adoption or a supplemental report as ordered by the Court as to the suitability of the child for adoption,. The report shall also contain the financial, moral and physical fitness and general background of the adoptive home and of the adoptive parent or parents. A home study shall be conducted as part of this procedure. The child welfare caseworker shall contact agencies and individuals having knowledge of the character and fitness of the adopting parents, and such information shall be included in the report. The child welfare caseworker shall make written recommendations on the proposed adoption.

Other Agencies and Individuals: The Court may also order other appropriate agencies or individuals to prepare and file written reports with the Court to aid in the Court's determination on the suitability of the proposed adoption.
Copies: Copies of reports shall be served on the petitioner at the same time they are presented to the Court.
Written consent to adoption is required of:

Each biological, adoptive and acknowledged parent whose parental rights have not been involuntarily terminated, who has not voluntarily terminated his/her parental right or has not been declared incompetent;
The guardian or custodian is empowered to consent;
The Court, if the guardian or custodian is not empowered to consent; and
The minor, if he/she is over twelve (12) years of age.
Written consent to an adoption is not required if:
The parent's rights have been involuntarily terminated;
The parent has voluntarily terminated his/her parental rights; or
The parent has been declared incompetent.

section.heading: Procedure for Signing the Consent to Adopt.
section.text: Written consent, where required by this Code, shall be attached to the petition for adoption. Written consent to an adoption shall be signed and acknowledged before the Court. Consent shall be accepted or acknowledged by the Court unless signed and acknowledged more than ten (10) days after birth of the child. An interpreter shall be provided if required by the Court.

section.heading: Withdrawal of Consent to Adopt.
section.text: Written consent to an adoption cannot be withdrawn after the entry of a final order of adoption. Consent may be withdrawn prior to the final order of adoption upon a showing by a preponderance of the evidence at a hearing before the Court that the consent was obtained by fraud, duress or coercion.

para.text: Purpose and Time Limit: A hearing shall be held within ninety (90) days of receipt of an adoption petition for the purpose of determining if it is in the minor's best interest to be placed with the petitioners.

Procedure at Hearing: The adoptive parent or parent(s) shall appear personally at the hearing. At or before the hearing, any biological, adoptive, or acknowledged parent who is consenting to the adoption must appear personally before the Judge, in open court, so that the Court can determine the understanding with which the consent was given. All other persons, whose consent is necessary to the adoption, shall be duly notified. The Judge shall examine all persons appearing as to suitability of the child for adoption, the validity of the consent to the adoption, and the financial, moral, and physical fitness and responsibility of the adoptive parent(s), and that the best interests of the child will be promoted by the adoption.
Order.
Granting the Petition: If the Court is satisfied that it is in the best interests of the child to grant the petition, the Court may enter a final decree of adoption as follows:
In the case of a child who has lived with the adoptive parent for more than six months before the adoption petition has been filed, the final decree of adoption shall be entered immediately; and

In all other cases, the Court shall order that the child be placed in the legal custody of the adoptive parent until the child has lived with the adoptive parent for at least six (6) months. At the expiration of the six (6) months, the Court shall request a supplemental report and, thereafter, if the Court determines that the best interests of the child are served by the adoption, it shall enter the final decree of adoption immediately.

Denying the Petition: If the Court is satisfied that the adoption petition will not be in the best interests of the child, the petition shall be denied. The Court may request the Indian Child Welfare Act (ICWA) Director to provide such services, to assist in the placement and care of the child. In any case where the Court finds that the best interests of the child will not be served by the adoption, a guardian of the person shall be appointed and suitable arrangements made for the care of the child, in accordance with the applicable provisions of this Code.

Confidentiality: All records, reports, proceedings and orders in adoption cases are confidential and permanent records of the Court shall be sealed and shall not be available for release to or inspection by the public.

Release of Information; Notice to Biological Parent: Information contained in such records shall be released upon petition to the Court by the adopted person after reaching legal age or majority, or upon order of the Court upon showing of good and sufficient cause by persons other the adopted person who have petitioned for such information. In either case, no information shall be released unless:
The biological parent(s) has been given actual and confidential notice by the Court.
The biological parent has consented, in writing, the release of information; or that the Court determines that the need for information is greater than the biological parent's right to privacy.

section.heading: Contents of Adoption Order.
section.text: The final order of adoption shall include such facts as are necessary to establish that the child is eligible and suitable for adoption, and that the adoptive home and parents are adequate and capable of providing the proper care of the child, as shown by the investigation reports and the findings of the Court upon the evidence produced at the hearings.

section.heading: Adoptive Birth Certificate; Release of Original Certificate.
section.text: Within five (5) days after the final decree of adoption has been entered by the Court, the Bureau of Vital Records of the State Department of Health of the state which issued the original certificate of birth shall be notified by the Clerk of the Court that the adoption has taken place, giving the full name, sex, birthday and names of the natural parents, in order that a new record of birth in the new name and with the name or names of the adoptive parents can be recorded. The state agency must be provided with a certified copy of the final decree of adoption.

section.heading: Name and Legal Status of Adopted Child.
section.text: Minor children adopted by order of the Court shall assure the surname of the persons by whom they are adopted, unless the Court orders otherwise. They shall be entitled to the same rights as children of heirs of the persons adopting them. However, the adoption does not confer Tribal membership status on the adopted children who would not be otherwise eligible.

para.text: The Children's Court shall have the authority, whenever it appears necessary or convenient, to appoint guardians for the persons and/or the estates, or for the purpose of actual or contemplated litigation (guardian ad litem) of minors incompetent by reason of physical or mental illness or deficiency, or chronic use of drugs or alcohol.
The Children's Court shall have the authority to appoint guardians when the child for whom the guardianship is sought is a member of the Tribe, whether or not he/she lives on the Pueblo of Picuris.

section.heading: Power to Appoint Guardians for Minors.
section.text: The Pueblo of Picuris Children's Court is empowered to appoint a guardian, either of the person or of the estate or both.

section.heading: Appointment of Guardian in Connection with Probating an Estate.

para.text: The Court may, in the process of administering an estate for which there is a valid will containing a designation of a guardian for minor children if orphaned by the death of the parent, appoint the person therein designated as guardian of the minor(s) involved without the necessity of a separate guardianship hearing.

If the person so designated is unable to or unwilling to serve, or if such person's appointment is objected to by any child over fourteen (14) years of age, or if the Court deems such to be in the minor's best interests, a separate guardianship hearing shall be held as provided herein.

Except as provided in the preceding Section, guardianship proceedings shall be initiated by the filing of a petition by a relative or other person on behalf of the minor, or by a minor him/herself if over fourteen (14) years of age. The Court may initiate proceedings to appoint a guardian if such appointment reasonably appears necessary and no other person has initiated such proceedings.

The petition shall set forth the name of the petitioner; the petitioner's relationship to the minor or incompetent, shall list all known relatives of the minor or incompetent and their addresses, relationships and ages insofar as is known to a petitioner; shall list all property of the minor or incompetent, real and personal, known to the petitioner; shall list in detail the present conditions and circumstances which warrant the appointment of a guardian; shall pray that Letters of Guardianship be issued to him/herself or some other suitable person to act as guardian of the minor.

The petitioner, or the Clerk of the Court, if a minor or the Court itself initiates the proceeding, shall cause notice of the hearing to be given by mail or personal service to all known interested persons listed on the petition not less than five (5) days before a scheduled hearing. Such notice need not be given in the case of a minor whose parent(s) appear and consent to waive such notice prior to the hearing. An appearance and waiver may be made personally or by affidavit to the Court.
Hearing: At a hearing conducted to appoint a guardian for a minor, the Court shall:
Examine the petition;
Determine the need to have a guardian appointed;
Examine the minor, if over fourteen (14) years of age, to determine who he/she would prefer to have as his/her guardian;
Determine which person, either the petitioner or some other person, is most suitable to act as guardian, and that person's willingness to act as such; and
Make an order appointing a guardian, setting forth the scope of the guardian's authority, whether or not security for his/her performance is to be required, and the duration of such appointment.

section.heading: Who May Serve As Guardian.
section.text: Any adult person twenty-one (21) years of age or older and subject to the jurisdiction of the Pueblo of Picuris Tribal Court may serve as a guardian. Preference shall be given to relatives of the minor in order of their closeness of relationship and some preference shall be given to a person with whom the minor is living with at the time of the guardianship hearing. Preference shall be given to the person preferred to act as his/her guardian by a minor over fourteen (14) years of age, but in all cases, the Court shall determine the best interests of the minor in selecting a guardian.

para.text: The guardian appointed by the Court shall be required to take an oath, the form of which is to be prescribed by the Court, to the effect that he/she will faithfully perform his/her duties as guardian.
Upon taking the oath, the guardian shall be issued an Order as evidence of his/her appointment. Any limitations in the authority of the guardian shall be set forth in the Order so issued.

Within forty-five (45) days after the appointment of a general guardian or guardian of the property or estate of a minor, the guardian shall prepare and submit to the Court an inventory and appraisement of the estate.
The appraisement shall be made by three (3) disinterested persons who shall certify, under oath, to their appraisement and may receive reasonable compensation for their services.

No appraisement shall be required of items of obvious, readily ascertainable value (e.g. bank account assets) or where the value of the estate is reasonably believed by the guardian to be less than one-thousand dollars ($1,000.00). If no appraisement is required, the guardian shall certify, under oath, to the obvious or estimated value of the assets not appraised.

The guardian of every estate in value over one-thousand dollars ($1,000.00) shall submit an annual account of the estate to the Court for approval, on such notice as the Court may direct, in each year in which the value of the estate is or is reasonably believed to be in excess of one- thousand dollars ($1,000.00).

Such account shall be verified, on the oath of the guardian, and shall contain an accounting of all additions to and withdrawals from the estate, and shall be accompanied by supporting cancelled checks, vouchers, receipts, statements, etc.
No guardian shall receive any compensation for acting as such without the prior approval of the Court.
Except as otherwise specifically ordered or limited by the Court:

A guardian of a minor shall have the right to take or provide for the custody of the minor and shall be required to care for the health, safety, and welfare of such a minor and provide for their education and medical care as needed or appropriate.

A general guardian or guardian of the estate of property of a minor shall have the authority to invest, manage and dispose of the property of the minor in a prudent and reasonable manner and expend such portions of the estate, income and then principle, as he/she shall deem reasonably necessary for the support, care, including medical care, and education of the minor given the size and nature of the estate and the station in life and needs of the minor.

A guardian ad litem shall have the power and authority to represent a minor's best interests in actual, threatened or contemplated litigation or other proceedings of a legal nature (other than of a criminal nature and/or under this Code), and to employ counsel, and settle or compromise suits or claims, subject to the approval of the Court.

A guardian of any kind may petition the Court for authority to do any act about which he/she is uncertain of his/her authority, and the Court may grant such authority, after such notice and hearing, if any, as the Court may direct, if such appears to be consistent with the best interests of the minor.

A guardian of any kind shall stand in a fiduciary relationship to the minor; shall exercise a high degree of care in managing the estate of his/her ward; shall derive no personal benefit of any kind from his/her management of the estate of his/her ward; and shall be civilly liable to said ward for any losses to the estate attributable to a breach of these duties. Action to enforce such liability may be brought by the ward or a subsequently appointed guardian on behalf of the ward within two (2) years after the appointment of the new guardian or the removal of the incompetency or the arriving at the age of majority.
Every guardian appointed as provided herein shall serve until discharged by the Court.

A guardian of a minor, not otherwise incompetent, or the minor him/herself, may petition the Court on or after the date the minor reaches the age of majority to have the guardian discharged and the estate turned over to the minor. The Court shall grant such discharge with or without notice and hearing, upon the receipt of sufficient, competent evidence that the minor has reached the age of majority unless the minor appears to be otherwise incompetent, in which case a hearing shall be held to determine such fact.

section.heading: Guardianship Records.
section.text: The Clerk shall keep a separate, permanent file for each guardianship proceedings and shall file all papers relevant thereto, including petitions, notices, orders for hearing, etc. Any guardian duly appointed shall be entitled to receive, without charge, three (3) certified copies of the Letters of Guardianship. Certified copies of filed papers shall be otherwise available at a fee per copy to be established by the Court.

section.heading: Guardianship of Trust Property.
section.text: The Court is hereby authorized to appoint a Guardian of the Trust Estate of Minors, using the procedures and safeguards outlined herein for the purpose of conveying or consenting to the conveyance of an interest in trust property owned by such minor or ward of the Court if it appears that the price to be paid is reasonable and adequate and that such sale is in the best interests of said minor or ward of the Court, the Court may enter an order authorizing such action.

section.heading: Temporary Guardianship and Custody.
section.text: The Court shall have the power to entertain and grant or deny petitions for temporary guardianship and custody when it determines it to be in the best interests of the child involved.

para.text: Any minor who is eligible to be a qualified student for purposes of the New Mexico Public School Finance Act shall attend a public school, private school, charter school or approved home school program. A minor shall be excused from this requirement if:
Exempted by Court Order;
The minor has graduated from a high school or has successfully completed the General Educational Development (GED) exams and has received a certificate;

The minor is at least seventeen (17) years of age and excused by the Superintendent of the local school district, in an alternative form of education sufficient for his/her educational needs and his/her parent(s), guardian(s), or custodian(s) consents.
A minor shall attend school for the length of time during the school year established for the school.
The parent(s), guardian, or custodian is responsible for the minor's school attendance.

section.heading: Traditional Religious Participation or Healing.
section.text: A student may be excused to participate in tribal religious or healing activities with the written excuse of the Governor of the Pueblo of Picuris or his designated representative.

para.text: The Board of Education of the local school district and the governing body of a public and/or charter school shall initiate the enforcement of the provisions of the Compulsory School Attendance Law [22-12-1 NMSA 1978] for students enrolled in their respective schools.

To initiate enforcement of the provisions of the Compulsory School Attendance Law against an habitual truant, a local school board or governing authority of a private and/or charter school or its authorized representatives shall give written notice of the habitual truancy by certified mail to or by personal service on the parent(s), guardian(s) or custodian(s) of the student subject to and in noncompliance with the provisions of the Compulsory School Attendance Law.

If unexcused absences continue after written notice of habitual truancy, as provided in Subsection B of this Section has occurred, the student shall be reported to the Indian Child Welfare Act (ICWA) office of the Pueblo of Picuris for an investigation as to whether the student shall be considered to be a neglected child or a child in a family in need of services because of habitual truancy and thus subject to the provisions of the Pueblo of Picuris Children's Code [32A-1-1 NMSA 1978]. In addition to any other disposition, the Children's Court may order the habitual truant's driving privileges to be suspended for a specified time not to exceed ninety (90) days on the first finding of a habitual truancy and not to exceed one year for a subsequent finding of habitual truancy.

If, after review by the Pueblo of Picuris ICWA Office, a determination and finding is made that the habitual truancy by the student may have been caused by the parent(s) of the student, then the matter will be referred by the Pueblo of Picuris IWCA Office to the Pueblo of Picuris Children's Court for filing of charges allowed under the Compulsory School Attendance Law. Charges against the parent may be filed in the Pueblo of Picuris Tribal Court.

A parent of a student, after receiving written notice as provided in Subsection B of this Section and after the matter has been reviewed in accordance with Subsection D of this Section, knowingly allows the student to continue to violate the Compulsory School Attendance Law shall be guilty of a Class C Offense. Upon the first conviction, a fine of not less than twenty- five dollars ($25.00) or more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) may be imposed, or the parent of the student may be ordered to perform community service. If violations of the Compulsory School Attendance Law continue, upon the second and subsequent convictions, the parent(s) of the student who knowingly allows the student to continue to violate the Compulsory School Attendance Law shall be guilty of a Class B Offense and shall be subject to a fine of not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or imprisonment for a definite term not to exceed six (6) months or both.

section.heading: Requirements.
section.text: The Pueblo of Picuris Children's Court may declare a child emancipated either pursuant to a petition or as a dispositional alternative if the child:

para.text: Wishes to be free from parental control and protection and no longer needs that control and protection; or
Is a minor-in-need-of-care or a delinquent child as defined by this Code; and all of the following exist.

section.heading: Requirements for Emancipation.
section.text: Before a minor may be emancipated, he/she must:

para.text: Be sixteen (16) years of age; and
Be self-supporting; and
Understand the consequences of being free from parental control and protections; and
Have an acceptable plan for independent living.

Petition: A minor may petition the Pueblo of Picuris Children's Court for a declaration of emancipation. The verified petition shall state specific facts, which will support a declaration of emancipation.
Notice: Before the petition is heard, notice shall be given to the minor's parent(s), guardian, or custodian as required by this Code.

Findings: If the Court finds that the requirements of Section 10-17-2 are met, the Court may grant the petition, unless, after having considered all of the evidence, it finds that emancipation would not be in the best interests of the child.
Declaration: If the Court grants the petition, it shall immediately issue a declaration of emancipation.

section.heading: Purpose for Emancipation.
section.text: An emancipated minor is subject to the continuing jurisdiction of the Pueblo of Picuris Children's Court and is subject to the laws requiring compulsory school attendance until he/she reaches the age of eighteen (18) or meets the requirements of Section 10-16-1 of this Code.

section.heading: Child's Right to Support.
section.text: The father and mother of a child, whether married or not, are jointly liable for the support of a child until he/she reaches eighteen (18) years of age, is emancipated, or their parental rights are severed. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the father and mother of a child may be liable for claims of restitution brought within the applicable claims period after the child reaches eighteen (18) years of age.

section.heading: Establishing Parentage.
section.text: The parentage of a child may be established by:

para.text: Written acknowledgment by a parent that he is the father of or she is the mother of the child and is filed with the Tribal Court; or
A judicial determination by the Tribal Court.
§10-17-3. Proceedings to Establish Parentage and Compel Support.

section.heading: Proceedings to Establish Parentage and Compel Support.

para.text: Proceedings to establish parentage may be brought at any time after the child is born and before the child is eighteen (18) years of age by a parent or by the minor acting through a guardian if the complainant dies or becomes disabled, or by the Tribe.

Proceedings to compel support from a parent may be brought in the Court at any time after the child is born or last supported by the parent and shall be brought by a complaining parent, by the minor if the complainant parent dies or becomes disabled, or by the Tribe.
To determine parentage, the Court shall consider evidence including but not limited to:
Deoxyribonucleic Acid (DNA) test results;
Testimony of the alleged father or mother;
Birth and baptismal certificates;
Testimony of the alleged parent's family members;
Clanship and other demonstrations of family ties, including purification rites and care provided to the minor.

To determine support obligations, the Court shall consider each parent's capacity or financial support and in-kind contributions and, if necessary, order wage-withholdings to enforce a support order. To achieve equitable and adequate child support standards, the Court may adopt and utilize as Tribal Law, the provisions from the State of New Mexico Child Support Guidelines, until such time as child support guidelines have been adopted by the Tribe.

Nothing in this Section shall preclude an action in the Tribal Court to establish parentage or support. A final ruling in the Children's Court on the matter will be binding in the Tribal Court and a final ruling in the Tribal Court on the matter will be binding in the Children's Court, as consistent with the rules of the Court.
Form of Petition; Summons; Procedures.

The petition shall be on the form approved by the Tribal Court and shall charge the person names as respondent with being the father or mother of the minor and demand that such person be compelled to support the minor;
Summons shall be issued and served as required by this Code; and
Procedure shall be the same as in other Children's Code actions.
Judgments: The Court shall enter its order determining the child's parentage and support, if any, and the conclusion of the adjudicatory hearing.

section.heading: Starting and Completing Proceedings.
section.text: Proceedings may be started before the birth of the child, but, unless the alleged father consents, trial will not be held until at least fifteen (15) days after the birth of the child.

section.heading: Rights of a Child Once Parentage is Established.
section.text: After the parentage of a child is established, the child has the same rights of inheritance from the person who is established as a parent that a child born as a result of a lawful marriage has under Tribal Law.

section.heading: Procedure.
section.text: An appeal to the Southwest Intertribal Court of Appeals (SWITCA) may be taken from any order, decree, or judgment of the Children's Court. Such an appeal shall be taken in the same manner in which appeals are taken from judgments or decrees of the Tribal Court. Except as otherwise provided in this Code, the appeal must be taken within one month from the entry of the order, decree, or judgment appealed from.

section.heading: Stay Pending Appeal.
section.text: Unless the Court stays its order, the pendency of an appeal shall not stay the order or judgment appealed from in a child's case. Where the order or decree appealed from directs a change of legal custody of a child, the appeal shall be heard and decided at the earliest practicable time. The name of the child shall not appear on the record on appeal.
